stance_justification: The writer presents their view of professionalism as definitive fact ('Part of being professional is...') and provides directive advice using 'should' language without acknowledging alternative approaches or uncertainty. They treat professional boundaries and appropriate responses as having clear, objectively correct answers rather than contextual judgments.
stance_markers: ["Part of being professional is", "you respect that", "don't get upset", "try to show some body language", "you'd rather not", "you'd like the talk to end"]
text:
Part of being professional is establishing personal boundaries and respecting others'. If someone wants to name his/her kid Ainsleigh, you respect that and don't get upset over someone else's personal choice that doesn't affect your daily activities. On the flip side, if people want to constantly engage you in conversation, try to show some body language that implies that you'd rather not hold a conversation too long: shoulders away from them, or just a smile instead of a verbal response to indicate that you'd like the talk to end.

What is your ideal situation of you socializing with your coworkers or your coworkers approaching you?

He has a point. Although he advices the ‚Äúfake it till you make it‚Äù route, essentially. I‚Äôm in the ‚Äúwomen should be a part of your life, never the main focus‚Äù camp. Which basically has the same effect, but you‚Äôre not lying. OP sounds like he did a lot of work to become a better version of himself, physically and mentally. Keep working on your health, your financial situation, your social life and your spiritual fulfillment. 

That‚Äôs called being on your path or on your purpose. And a woman should be an addition to your life, not a ball and chain. Which one of those she becomes is up to you, OP. Have clear, righteous boundaries and don‚Äôt be afraid to enforce them. Even it it feels like you risk losing her, it‚Äôs worth it. Women have no respect for a man they can walk all over. And that‚Äôs a far worse scenario than losing her because she‚Äôs mad that you didn‚Äôt allow her to make you unhappy. That‚Äôs not their job. 

Congratulations OP, and good luck

Stop overthinking it. Just introduce yourself to anyone you would like to speak to. If someone came up to you and said ‚ÄúHey how are you? My name is ________ what‚Äôs yours?‚Äù Would you see that person as awkward or feel awkward yourself? Probably not. 

I find it‚Äôs easier to just say what‚Äôs on your mind when conversing, you only really need to think about you‚Äôre saying when speaking about a sensitive topic. Causal conversation flows naturally, trust me. And if it doesn‚Äôt that‚Äôs okay too. We are not machines that need to speak 24/7, especially when on a hike where most are too busy taking in gorgeous views.

text:
1) If you have somewhere to go or something to do or want to continue your day, it's no problem to give a "Well I have work to do/ a prior engagement/ I'm heading off/ I gotta bounce/ I gotta get lunch" whatever works for you

2) If neither you or the other party have other priorities there's nothing wrong with just hanging out and allowing a lull in conversation to happen.  You're allowed to just relax, you don't have to be 'on' or talk constantly.  I've spent many hours with my best pals not saying a damn word and not feeling awkward at all.

stance_justification: The writer explicitly states that 'neither way of communicating is right or wrong, it's just different' and refuses to evaluate which approach might be more effective in different contexts. They present the conflict as simply a matter of different communication styles without weighing the merits of directness versus indirectness, treating both as equally valid approaches that just need accommodation.
stance_markers: ["neither way of communicating is 'right' or 'wrong', it's just different", "it's just different", "taking the attitude that the other person's way of communicating is 'wrong'", "the one who's 'wrong' needs to learn the 'right' way"]
text:
I know EXACTLY what you mean! I have the same problem with a lot people, especially my family. My Mother felt that being direct was low-class. For example: if you're offered something to eat/ drink that you don't like, you're to say " No thank you, I don't care for any. " because it could be thought that you just don't want any. When I asked her why I couldn't just say I don't like it, she told me that it just wasn't done. You weren't allowed to do that if you were a person of 'refinement'. ( rolling my eyes and shaking my head)

I've thought about this very subject and I came to the conclusion that my way of thinking was like being visually impaired; my family is like a hearing impaired person who can only understand sign language. When I hear someone near me, I vocalize. I can't see so I don't realize that they are signing to me. They don't realize that I can't see so they keep signing more and I keep vocalizing louder, and so it goes.

For the record: neither way of communicating is 'right' or 'wrong', it's just different. Somehow or another, there has to be a way for both parties to communicate and be heard.And it isn't going to happen if we keep doing what we're doing and taking the attitude that the other person's way of communicating is 'wrong' and that the the one who's 'wrong' needs to learn the 'right' way.

Again for the record: I expect the program to show me the scenes that are important to the understanding of the story. I've not seen the program, but I agree with the OP of this subject.

text:
I can tell you one thing already;

You are still relatively young and you will definitely make one or more friends until your death, although I would advise you not to talk about your eventual life like that.

I know your current situation to the extent that you feel very lonely and empty right now and don't know whether you really need friends or should look for friends or whether you need a relationship.

In your message you talk about a lot of small problems and it is difficult to go into everything individually but i try my best  


1. &#x200B;

It's your life and of course you have to decide for yourself if you want to have friends. We can't dictate anything to you. But having one or more friends will help you in every point of view. You can go out with friends and do something, you can meet them, play games or travel with them. You can talk to them, talk about such problems/thoughts and get their opinion. you can do so much

Of course there will also be arguments, a possible break or you might get injured, but that's all human.

2

Having a relationship can also improve/beautify your life in many ways. You have someone you trust very strongly, who loves you as you know it from films/series/books etc. Hugs or sex will give you a lot of feelings of happiness/moments that you probably haven't really known before or can imagine.

Of course, problems can also arise here, but they are human again.

So in short:

Having friends or having a girlfriend has so many advantages and it improves your life in every aspect.

The other problem you indirectly posed is how to get there.

For that I can recommend you the posts in the pinned post on the Reddit server or you can read my older messages on other posts that (almost) all had the same problem as one should/can friends.

stance_justification: The writer presents their advice as reasoned judgment ('IMO') rather than absolute truth, provides a logical sequence of steps with explanations for why each matters, and shows metacognitive awareness of contradictions in their own approach ('The trick here is...'). They acknowledge the complexity and challenge of their advice ('Which is hard because...') and demonstrate self-reflection about their own tendencies toward condescension.
stance_markers: ["IMO", "You have to decide", "The trick here is", "Which is hard because", "Which is a challenge I face", "because I'm an ok guy"]
text:
> How do I relate with others? Through reading, exercise, hobbies? How should I be interesting and easily hold chemistry with people?

IMO, do you first.  You have to decide what you want to do with yourself, who do you want to be, what you enjoy doing.

Do those things, be comfortable and happy with an identity of yourself exposed through your actions, interests, and choices.

Then you are interesting to people because you are doing things that they aren't, you can talk about those things, you can talk about the things others do that you don't, and why.

The trick here is to actual give a shit about people.  Which is hard because to start with you have to not give a shit.  You become who you want to be on your terms by not caring about what others think.

But when you want to then relate to people, you need to actually care again.

Also, you need to not be condescending.  Which is a challenge I face, ~~because I am literally the best person in the world~~ because I'm an ok guy

stance_justification: The writer consistently frames their position as objectively correct ('I know I'm right', 'you're right in your head') and dismisses opposing views as 'complete rubbish' and 'stupid opinions'. They treat disagreement as a matter of others being wrong or defensive rather than having legitimate alternative perspectives, showing the absolutist pattern of believing there is one right answer.
stance_markers: ["I know I'm right", "you're right in your head", "complete rubbish", "stupid opinions", "ignorantly happy", "I'm trying to have an intellectually stimulating arguement and try to use facts and logic", "you're not narrow-minded are are simply an intelligent guy"]
text:
I'm the EXACT same as you (except I usually refuse to admit we're both right). People say I'm relentless and narrow-minded even though I'm trying to have an intellectually stimulating arguement and try to use facts and logic. 

Personally, I think people who like to debate/argue are hard to like. People have a variety of beliefs about different things even if they're complete rubbish. But lots of people don't want to constantly be corrected on their stupid opinions, they'd rather keep them and be ignorantly happy. They are likely to go super-defensive and make up complete crap in order to protect their views and don't see these situations as an opportunity to exchange opinions or ideas.

On coming to that realisation, it became easier to avoid arguements because I stopped caring about trying to persuade the other person. My pride is in myself and I know I'm right, so it's fine. You have to trust in yourself that you're not narrow-minded are are simply an intelligent guy who likes to argue (it's not a bad thing). 

But then, if you want to maintain friendships with these people you have to decide. Either stop arguing so much and be happy knowing you're right in your head (you'll have to do things such as changing the subject or simply not voicing your conflicting opinions), or find better friends. Personally I find that with such people I just maintain a shallow relationship and make my close relationships with the people that actually know the rules of arguing and debating. 

If you're reliant on these friends, maybe keep them sweet until you get the opportunity to make friends with people that are more like you. 

My opinion, anyway. Dont know if its relevant :)

stance_justification: The writer presents sweeping generalizations as definitive truths ('People often times...talk about such meaningless shit', 'chicks prefer a guy with an air of mystery', 'I found the truth of the universe'). text:
Well, first of all, did someone actually straight up approach you and condemned or criticized you for that? Because I personally wouldn't mind or even care if I was hanging with you and you were to pull 'that' off. And I would definitely not bother evaluating it as an observer and recipient. Purely because it's not really a big deal. It's not even a deal of any kind. People often times, especially us milennials, talk about such meaningless shit, that it never ceazes to amaze me, that actually 'those' people usually find themselves within a huge circle. Do you know why? It's the small talk and 'those' guys constantly have a mouth full of it. Though it's not apparent at first, small talk is the number 1 easiest way to establish a foundation with pretty much any human being, so long as they allow you to by listening. And it doesn't have to be about anything important or relevant. It literally can and often is about meaningless shit.
So, in answer to your dilemma: no. You're not weird. If anything, you stand out from the crowd by having those two unique traits that make you who you are.  Now, maybe if you were trying to attract a girl, that bit about you sharing too much personal information would be kinda perceived as a slight turn-off (not claiming it would for sure), but that's only because chicks prefer a guy with an air of mystery about them ;) Unless you're going for the friend-zone, then by all means! They love having emotional male friends around them. 
I speak from my experience, because in a way I too was somewhat similar to you. I thought that by being open about literally every aspect of my life, with a chick I liked, was gonna make her warm up to me and trust me and stuff like that. And it was working precisely like that, alright! But not in the right direction I wanted it to go, instead drifting off to.. where? Yes, friend-zone. So I did find myself wondering about it too. What the hell? My mum taught me to be a gentleman after all. So I was. Then, years later I found channel on Youtube called BasedZeus and everything started to come to me straight. I found the truth of the universe. Chicks love bad guys who don't give two shits about them and then ghost them, when girls try to reach them in text. And you'd be amazed, but it started to work for me like immediately, as soon as I applied those principals. I swear to God, ghosting a chick on Messenger or text is the biggest turn on for her. Because for all she knows, you have got such busy and amazing life that u didn't even have time to pick up the phone.
Nah, but seriously, you're okay, dude. Again if I was talking to you, I wouldn't even notice anything weird about this. And also, that bit about u being too open, I daresay if anything, it'll make people like you more. That's just my perspective though.

Also, sorry! I just assumed you're a dude, for the benefit of the story.

stance_markers: ["Maybe she didn't like...", "Maybe she was busy", "What if you thought...", "who knows, that could be the case", "you ought to respect that", "could definitely be considered", "How you feel is largely on you", "Sometimes they have bad days"]
text:
Everyone is different bruh. Maybe she didn't like the question. Maybe she didn't like the question coming from the new person. Maybe she was busy. Maybe she had other things on her mind and didn't want to make small talk about her dog at that time. 

What if you thought the question was nice but for whatever reason she thought it wasn't nice? I mean who knows, that could be the case. And if it were the case you ought to respect that, and if you don't respect it then you aren't being nice anyway. Asking what you consider to be a nice question and then expecting a nice reply could definitely be considered a rude and entitled attitude. And I mean it sounds like you're now doubling down on that by ignoring her now. 

So yeah my advice would be to be nice. But by nice I mean be open minded and flexible. Try not to get twisted up over small slights. How you feel is largely on you, and how you react is absolutely 100% on you. People aren't like vending machines where you put in a nice question and get out a nice response or something. Sometimes they have bad days or whatever

stance_justification: The writer presents their position as objective truth using definitive language like 'the only way to do that is' and 'you *do* get better.' They dismiss alternative approaches without genuine engagement, framing disagreement as ignorance ('Have you ever actually studied fighting?'). The entire argument treats their perspective as fact rather than a reasoned judgment.
stance_markers: ["Have you ever actually studied fighting?", "the only way to do that is", "you *do* get better", "you *do* just have to", "We all suffer in life", "it's your choice"]
text:
Have you ever actually studied fighting?  Perhaps boxing?  "Learn to take a punch (and keep going)" is one of the fundamentals, and the only way to do that is to get punched, repeatedly.  Yeah, it sucks, but no matter how good you are at dodging or avoidance, sometimes it's unavoidable.  A boxer who gets KO'ed after one punch isn't a good boxer.  Have you done any strenuous exercise, like long-distance running or weight-lifting?  I can tell you that that shit hurts and is strenuous; sometimes you *do* just have to tough your way through it. Learn from the experience, and using that wisdom, lessen the aches.  With experience, you *do* get better at handling missteps.  

Not everything that hurts you should be viewed as an antagonistic combat sport, because most people aren't out to actively hurt you (and those who are should *absolutely* be avoided).  

Asking someone out and getting rejected *is* practice for future encounters.  We all suffer in life, and it's your choice to either learn from it or not.  Hiding in the basement is still a form of suffering, you know.

I‚Äôm sorry, dude, but it‚Äôs not MY worldview I‚Äôm speaking from‚Äî it‚Äôs neurotypicals‚Äô. You‚Äôre just not in a position where you can be determining the intent of their behavior, simply because you aren‚Äôt them. Any ‚Äúassumptions‚Äù i made about you that weren‚Äôt explicitly supported by what you‚Äôve already said, I did actually preface with the word ‚Äúmaybe‚Äù, because... I‚Äôm just speculating. No big deal; if it doesn‚Äôt apply to you then why call attention to it by denying what I never claimed to be true in the first place? 

For resources (which you didn‚Äôt ask for? but whatever) you can literally just... learn about neurotypical psychology, instead of assuming that you somehow magically know them better than they know themselves. Also maybe google some information on the nuances of what manipulation actually is, because your definition does not align with the rest of the world‚Äôs definition, which makes it wrong because that‚Äôs how language works. I‚Äôm not your high school teacher and you‚Äôre perfectly capable of learning for yourself, and honestly I‚Äôm not about to argue a rando on the internet over the subject of my degree. üòê like, you‚Äôre not disagreeing with ME here, because I very much understand your train of thought and can empathize, you‚Äôre arguing with like the last 30 years of advances in social psychology that are very easily accessible on the internet. If you want to actually learn instead of making assumptions without evidence, that‚Äôs up to you; I never had any interest in holding your hand through it. If you want to be spoon-fed this stuff then you should probably look into receiving higher education in that field instead of expecting strangers on the internet to do that work for you. It‚Äôs up to you, and I don‚Äôt really care either way; like I said, it‚Äôs not my opinion, it‚Äôs basically the unanimous consensus of modern neurotypical psychology. A good starting point would maybe be some of the more recent research done on prosocial behavior, empathy, and social mindfulness.

stance_justification: The writer presents their advice as a reasoned judgment rather than absolute truth, using qualifying language like 'If I were you, I would' and 'this is just my opinion.' They provide structured reasoning with specific criteria for self-evaluation (health, finances, relationships) and explain the logical connection between focusing inward and attracting better relationships. While confident in their recommendation, they acknowledge it as their perspective.
stance_markers: ["If I were you, I would", "this is just my opinion", "honestly, it couldn't matter less to me", "My best from", "You see", "The paradox of that is"]
text:
Happy birthday!!!

If I were you, I would **shift the frame of reference**. 

Meaning that: instead of caring too much if people care about my birthday, I would care less about what other people think of me and more about what I think about myself.

Things like: Another year has passed for me: 

* How I improved myself? 
* Is my health better or worse than last year? 
* Are my finances better or worse? 
* Are my relationships better or worse?

You see, our minds can focus on very few things at any given moment so if you focus on what matters, you don't have to spend mental energy on things that don't matter (again this is just my opinion but honestly, it couldn't matter less to me if people even know I have a birthday).

The paradox of that is that if you do just that, you will increase your worth in society as a healthier, richer, happier person. **And more people will start being attracted to you**. People that matter, people that want the best for you and will contribute to your well-being for many more happy birthdays :)

My best from [Social Dynamics Academy](https://socialdynamicsacademy.com/)

stance_justification: The writer presents their social practices as definitive rules without acknowledging alternative approaches or uncertainty. They use directive language ('fucking go', 'Be kind to yourself') and present their strategies as universally correct rather than personal preferences that work for them. There's no engagement with potential counterarguments or acknowledgment that different social styles might work for different people.
stance_markers: ["I always follow up", "fucking go and go at the understood time", "Nobody wants to", "The main thing I can recommend", "Be kind to yourself", "be the kind of friend you want to have"]
text:
I always follow up on plans even if I'm not planning on going. Whenever possible I let people have a for-sure answer whether we're doing something at a particular time/day/place. Nobody wants to keep a big question mark on their calendar hoping you make up your mind. If you say you're going, fucking go and go at the understood time.

I don't leave people on read if I have time to respond and I'm in anything above a truly bad headspace. It's about 50-50 on initiating conversations and plans but that wasn't always the case. I spent a lot of time initiating and following through on plans, so people are happy to invite me to parties and plans because I'm actually fun, I actually care, and I actually show up. 

At parties, I have a pretty good sense of who's there and doesn't want to be, who's there to get wasted, and who's looking to have a decent conversation and a lot of fun. I stick around the people who are there to have fun or at least open to it. I try to include everyone as much as possible but I'm not going to pry my way into someone's bubble who doesn't want to join the party. This is doubly true for people who've very clearly decided before arriving that they aren't going to enjoy themselves. 

The main thing I can recommend is practice and persistence until it becomes natural. Be kind to yourself in your choice of friends and be the kind of friend you want to have and model the kind of relationships you want to have.

text:
1) Yes it's 100% okay to go on multiple dates. Just be clear to the girl you're hanging out with that you don't jump into dating until at least a month or 2 in. Because you got to get to know them. Nothing polygamous about it. 

2) I doubt girls focus on one guy at a time (Not all girls). Girls cheat just as much as guys. And I am sure they have gotten comments from many many men. Wait to see how these girls react to you in the long run that you do what you want, they should want to keep your attention. The app deleting/Talking to no one else is a sign they want you long term (REALLY good sign), but it's UP TO YOU in the end what you want to do. Don't get emotional about your choice or feel bad, especially if you haven't been on a date yet. 

If a girl is talking to you. That is enough of a sign that she's interested in dating you. Even sometimes when she's not talking to you it's a sign she could be interested. Some people like to get testy with you to see how you'll react, but you have to be firm and confident in your action making. (But if a girl tells you to back off. Then BACK OFF. Period.)

As well, Meeting people in real life like bars, clubs, social gatherings can be WAY WAY better if you have a few hours on the weekend and the confidence to talk to a lot of girls. I have actually gotten a couple dates from girls I've met at bus stops (Not straight up "Lets date" but more like "Hi, What are you taking at university?".) Which can be much more rewarding when you meet the right girl. Be open. 

As for online dating, It's hit or miss for me. Some girls will give a lot of feedback, some not as much. Just stay focused, text once in a while, have a good time, try to set up a date when there is availability. Send a girl a joke or a story. If she doesn't reply send her something else in a couple days. And then ask her out within the next 2 days after that. Online dating is a long term game sometimes.

stance_justification: The writer explicitly defers evaluation at the outset ('I'm not going to explain how you should do it, since everyone has their own ways') and consistently treats all approaches as equally valid without weighing their relative merits. They acknowledge individual differences ('Everyone is different. They have different people they prefer to hang out with') but don't evaluate which strategies might be more effective in different situations.
stance_markers: ["everyone has their own ways", "Everyone is different", "They have different people they prefer to hang out with", "depending on the person", "That's just my to go advice"]
text:
that's fine, I'm not going to explain how you should do it, since everyone has their own ways.  But i'll give you my detail of some people i started knowing in my classes and how i met them.  Usually the people in my class whether they are a little bit further away or next to me.  The ones next to you are easier because they're next to you and you can just make a small conversation of like.  How did you do on the exam? or How was the homework?  Eventually you guys can lead to small subjects.  I sometimes compliment them on something if I really mean it.  Don't do it just to compliment but if you actually mean it, it has a bigger effect.  This girl I remember we just talked about school most the time.  I usually ask oh you taking any other classes besides this?  What's your major?  IF they're undecided, i usually say something to uplift them like im sure you'll find out what you want to do.  There is something you like to do right? :)  

I mostly talk about them and what they're into.  If you notice they seem to be a little bit annoyed then its time to back away.  You don't want to be the pushy interrogation guy.  You just want to know enough, and let it be.  Let them talk to you again instead.  Start over the next day.  Good morning or hows it going *name*.  How's ur day been?  and you can reset it again.  After a while you guys get used to each other depending on the person.  Everyone is different.  They have different people they prefer to hang out with.  My group around me we hung out together during the breaks of our classes because it was a Lab.  And we talked to each other because we needed help.  We ended up asking for each other's facebook.  And was like hey, what's do you got a facebook?  We could help each other on the work if anything.  That's just my to go advice.  Good luck!
